title: Freeway & Urban Driving Strategies
objectives: Merge smoothly using acceleration lanes without stopping unless required.
Select the correct freeway lane and use the left lane mainly for passing.
Identify and follow HOV (carpool) and express-lane rules and markings.
Manage speed under California’s basic speed law and changing conditions.
Maintain a safe following distance at freeway speeds and increase it in poor conditions.
Plan exits early, read interchange signs, and handle weaving areas safely.
Scan for urban hazards including intersections, frequent stops, and pedestrians.
Share the road with vulnerable users: bikes, scooters, buses, and light rail.
Apply city parking rules: curb colors, meters, time limits, and hill parking.
Handle special conditions: night glare, rain spray, hydroplaning, wind, and large-vehicle turbulence.

lessons.title: Acceleration Lanes & Ramp Meters
content: On-ramps and acceleration lanes exist to help you reach freeway speed before merging. Look far ahead and match the speed of traffic as you approach the merge area.
Use the entire acceleration lane. Do not stop on the ramp unless traffic or a signal requires it. Freeway traffic has the right of way.
Ramp meters are small signals that control how quickly vehicles enter. Obey the posted sign—often it is one vehicle per green per lane. Follow posted signs and local rules.
[object Object]

lessons.title: Merging Etiquette & Choosing a Gap
content: Use SMOG: Signal, Mirrors, Over‑the‑shoulder, Go when clear. Enter at or near traffic speed so others do not have to slow suddenly.
If a driver speeds up to block you, keep signaling and adjust to the next gap. Do not stop on the ramp unless a signal or stopped traffic requires it.
When two streams merge, be courteous and take turns if needed. Maintain lane position and communicate with your indicators.
[object Object]

lessons.title: Freeway Exits: Off‑ramps, Signals & Shoulder Use
content: Know your exit early. Move to the proper lane one at a time and signal for at least five seconds (about 400 ft) before exiting.
Follow any exit‑ramp signals and advisory speeds. Do not cross solid lines or the gore area to make a last‑second exit.
If you miss an exit, keep going to the next one. Never back up on the freeway.
[object Object]

lessons.title: Lane Numbers & Right vs. Left
content: On multilane roads, the leftmost lane is lane 1, then numbers increase to the right.
Use the left lane mainly for passing or left turns. Use right lanes for entering/exiting and for slower traffic.
Solid white lines mean do not change lanes; broken white lines allow a lane change when safe.
[object Object]

lessons.title: Passing & ‘Keep Right’ Habits
content: Pass on the left and return only when you can see the vehicle’s headlights in your rearview mirror.
Passing on the right is allowed only in specific situations (e.g., multiple same‑direction lanes or the other driver turning left). Never drive off the paved roadway to pass.
Do not linger in the left lane. If faster traffic approaches from behind, move right when safe.
[object Object]

lessons.title: Carpool (HOV) & Express Lanes
content: HOV lanes are marked with a diamond symbol and signs. They are for vehicles that meet posted occupancy, eligible clean‑air vehicles with DMV decals, and motorcycles (unless posted otherwise).
Never cross double‑solid white lines to enter or exit an HOV lane. Use designated entry/exit areas with broken lines.
Some corridors use express lanes with tolls or transponders. Follow posted signs and local rules.
[object Object]

lessons.title: California’s Basic Speed Law
content: Never drive faster than is safe for current conditions, regardless of the posted limit.
Typical maximum freeway speed is 65 mph unless posted otherwise. Slow for traffic, weather, visibility, and roadway surfaces.
Do not impede traffic by driving far below the flow; move right if needed and safe.
[object Object]

lessons.title: Following Distance at Freeway Speeds
content: Use the three‑second rule at a minimum. Increase following distance at higher speeds and in rain, darkness, or heavy spray.
If you are tailgated, keep your pace, then change to a right lane when safe to let the driver pass.
Avoid squeezing into small gaps. After merging, rebuild your space cushion.
[object Object]

lessons.title: Sight Distance, Escape Routes & Space Cushion
content: Scan at least 10 seconds ahead to spot slowdowns, debris, and lane drops early.
Avoid driving in other drivers’ blind spots. Create space on both sides whenever possible.
If you cannot see around a large vehicle, increase following distance or change lanes when safe.
[object Object]

lessons.title: Interchange Types & Signs
content: Interchanges (cloverleaf, diamond, trumpet) connect roads using ramps with curves and changing speeds. Expect limited sight distance on ramps.
Large broken lines often mark lane ends and exits. Watch for ‘EXIT ONLY’ and lane‑drop signs.
Weaving areas occur where entering and exiting paths cross. Look ahead, communicate with signals, and be patient.
[object Object]

lessons.title: Exit Planning, Lane Drops & Weaving
content: Move to the proper lane well before your exit. Signal for at least five seconds (about 400 ft) to communicate your intent.
Respect solid lines and gore areas. If you miss the exit, continue to the next one—never back up.
In weaving segments, take turns (‘zipper’) and avoid accelerating to block others.
[object Object]

lessons.title: Intersections & Frequent Stops
content: City streets have many close intersections. Expect frequent red lights and stop‑and‑go traffic.
Pedestrians have the right of way in marked and unmarked crosswalks. Yield and scan both sides.
Treat dark signals as all‑way stops. Do not enter an intersection unless you can fully clear it.
[object Object]

lessons.title: Lane Blockages: Double‑Parked, Deliveries, Rideshare
content: Expect delivery trucks, buses, and ride‑share vehicles to stop at curbs. People may walk out between vehicles.
Double‑parking is illegal. Never stop in a travel lane to load/unload.
Leave extra space on the right side of your lane and be ready to stop. Doors can open suddenly.
[object Object]

lessons.title: Bicycles, Scooters & the Door Zone
content: Bicycles share the road and may use the full lane when needed. Give them space and expect speed changes.
Leave at least three feet when passing. Change lanes to pass when necessary and safe.
The ‘door zone’ is hazardous. Check mirrors and over your shoulder before opening doors near traffic or bike lanes.
[object Object]

lessons.title: Bus‑Only Lanes, Light Rail & Transit Stops
content: Do not drive, stop, or park in a bus‑only lane. You may cross it to turn right where permitted.
At marked safety zones for streetcars or trolleys, pass at no more than 10 mph and watch for people.
Do not pass light rail on the left unless directed. Look for trains before crossing tracks.
[object Object]

lessons.title: Curb Colors, Meters & Time Limits
content: Curb colors: white = pick up/drop‑off, green = time‑limited, yellow = loading/commercial, red = no stopping, blue = disabled parking with placard/plates.
Read signs and meters for hours and time limits. Always follow posted signs and local rules.
Park within 18 inches of the curb when parallel parking.
[object Object]

lessons.title: Hills, Parallel Parking & No‑Parking Zones
content: On hills: turn wheels toward the curb when facing downhill; away from the curb when uphill; with no curb, turn toward the edge.
Parallel park by aligning, backing at ~45°, straightening, and ending within 18 inches of the curb.
Never park in crosswalks, in front of driveways, too close to hydrants, or in double‑parked positions.
[object Object]

lessons.title: Night Glare, Rain Spray & Hydroplaning
content: Use low beams in rain or fog and whenever wipers are on. Never drive with only parking lights.
At night, look to the right edge to avoid glare and slow so you can stop within the distance you can see.
In heavy rain, reduce speed and watch for standing water. If you begin to hydroplane, ease off the accelerator and avoid hard braking or sudden turns.
[object Object]

lessons.title: Wind, Big‑Rig Turbulence & Emergencies
content: Large vehicles create wind turbulence and have big blind spots. Do not linger beside them. Pass on the left and do not cut in.
Strong winds: slow down, grip the wheel, and be alert for debris. Avoid cruise control in gusty conditions.
If your vehicle breaks down, move to the right shoulder, turn on hazards, call for help (511/FSP where available), and stay in the vehicle with your seat belt fastened.
[object Object]
